text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator down every morning to the ground floor and then, except on rainy days, takes the elevator back up to the 10th floor and walks up five more floors.
Hmm, let's break this down.
First, he lives on the 15th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor, which is floor 1.
That makes sense because he's going to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and then walks up the remaining five floors to his apartment.
So, on normal days, he's saving himself from walking up 10 floors in the evening by taking the elevator part of the way.
But why doesn't he just take the elevator all the way up every evening? Maybe it's something about the elevator's behavior.
Wait, the problem says that on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.
So, on rainy days, he doesn't take the stairs at all.
That's different.
I wonder if the elevator has a limit.
Maybe on rainy days, the elevator can only go up to the 15th floor, but on normal days, it stops at the 10th floor.
Or perhaps the elevator's speed or availability changes with the weather.
Alternatively, maybe the man is trying to avoid getting wet or something, but that doesn't quite fit with the problem.
Wait, another angle: perhaps the elevator is out of order on rainy days, so it goes all the way up, but on normal days, it only goes up to the 10th floor.
Or maybe the man has a reason related to time.
For example, on rainy days, he might be in a hurry and doesn't want to walk up five floors, so he takes the elevator all the way.
But that doesn't explain why he takes the elevator part of the way on normal days.
Oh, maybe the elevator only goes up to the 10th floor on normal days, so he has to walk the rest.
On rainy days, the elevator goes all the way up to his floor, so he doesn't have to walk at all.
That makes sense.
So, the elevator's maximum height is the 10th floor on normal days, but on rainy days, it can go higher, up to the 15th floor.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator has a malfunction where it stops at the 10th floor on normal days but works properly on rainy days, allowing it to go higher.
That could be a reason why he takes the elevator all the way on rainy days.
So, putting it together, the man takes the elevator down every morning because he's going to work.
In the evening, on normal days, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor because the elevator only goes there, and then he walks up the remaining five floors.
But on rainy days, the elevator can go all the way up to the 15th floor, so he doesn't need to walk at all.
I think that's the main reason.
The elevator's operation is different based on the weather, so on rainy days, it's more convenient for him to take it all the way up.

</think>

The man takes the elevator down every morning to the ground floor because he's commuting to work.
In the evening, on normal days, he uses the elevator up to the 10th floor because the elevator likely has a limit or malfunction that prevents it from going higher.
He then walks up five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, the elevator functions normally and can take him all the way up to the 15th floor, eliminating the need to walk.
